meta.title: Talk to Me Like I'm Someone You Love
meta.subtitle: Use flash cards and vulnerability to transform conflict from toxic fighting to intimacy and connection.

why_matters.text: Relationship ruptures are often 'context failures'—how we treat each other—rather than 'content disputes.' These can be rapidly repaired by shifting from defensive verbal arguing to vulnerable written messages that bypass emotional flooding and re-establish safety.

analysis.heading: 1. Context Over Content
analysis.intro_text: Most fights are about how we are fighting (tone, facial expression, safety), not what we are fighting about. The book argues that you cannot resolve content until the context is safe. A request for better tone ('Talk to me like I'm someone you love') creates immediate context shift.

insight_card.title: The Tone Is the Message
insight_card.text: Content gets lost in the delivery. When the nervous system is in defense mode, the words do not land.

analysis.heading: 2. The Power of the Written Word
analysis.intro_text: When flooded, our verbal tone often betrays our best intentions (we sound angry even when saying 'I love you'). Written cards strip away the toxic tone, allowing the message to land purely. Using a prop also breaks the trance of the argument.

insight_card.title: Tone-Stripped Communication
insight_card.text: The written word removes the paralinguistic elements (tone of voice, facial expression) that trigger defensiveness, allowing the message to be received as intended.

analysis.heading: 3. Vulnerability as Strength
analysis.intro_text: The cards encourage 'leaning in' to vulnerability—admitting 'I'm scared you're leaving me' instead of screaming 'You're a jerk.' This disarms the partner's defense system and creates genuine connection.

insight_card.title: Soft Power
insight_card.text: Vulnerability is not weakness; it is the invitation to connection. When one person drops their defense, the other often follows.

analysis.heading: 4. Distrust as Data
analysis.intro_text: Instead of shaming 'paranoia,' the book encourages voicing distrust ('I'm scared you're lying') as a way to build trust. Bringing the shadow into the light makes it manageable.

insight_card.title: Speaking the Unspeakable
insight_card.text: The fears we cannot voice grow power in the dark. Speaking them—vulnerably, not accusingly—creates opportunity for repair.

actions.title: Rapid De-Escalation (The "Stop" Protocol)
actions.context: Use when you feel reactive anger/defensiveness rising to interrupt destructive cycles before major damage occurs.

steps.description: Heat, racing heart, racing thoughts—these signal flooding.
Do not try to finish the argument. Stop.

steps.bold_title: Use a "Shifting Gears" Card (Real or Mental)
steps.description: 'I feel like a bully and I don't know how to stop.' or 'I'm feeling defensive and can't hear you right now.'

steps.bold_title: Hand It Over or Say It Without Edge
steps.description: Deliver the message with genuine vulnerability, not sarcasm.

steps.bold_title: Wait for Their Nervous System to Shift
steps.description: Do not rush. The shift is a small softening—they need time to register it.

actions.title: The "Talk to Me Like I'm Someone You Love" Intervention
actions.context: Use when your partner is harsh or the tone has become toxic.

steps.description: Notice the harsh tone or words landing painfully.
Do not match their aggression. This escalates.
Say (or hold up a card): 'Talk to me like I'm someone you love.'
This is a request, not an attack. Stay calm and loving.
Their tone may immediately shift—or they may need to step away and come back. Both are okay.

actions.title: Vulnerable Disclosure
actions.context: Use to connect through shared humanity rather than winning points.

steps.description: Beneath anger is often fear, shame, or hurt. What are you really feeling?
'I'm afraid you're losing interest in me.' or 'I feel small and invisible right now.'
This is about your internal world, not their failure.
Vulnerability often disarms defensiveness. Watch for the shift.

steps.bold_title: Move Into Connection If Safety Is Established
steps.description: If they soften, move toward them. Comfort is now possible.

actions.title: Taking Responsibility
actions.context: Use to repair trust by owning your piece of the conflict.

steps.description: What did you do that made things worse? (Not 'But they started it.')

steps.bold_title: Select an Ownership Card (or Speak It)
steps.description: 'I realize I was taking my stress out on you.' or 'I see how that sounded critical.'
Do not follow with 'But you...' Own your piece cleanly.
Do not ask for immediate forgiveness. Simply state it and let the other person process.
